article.description: Lawrence McKenzie may have been facing Baylor for the first time, but he helped Oklahoma record a familiar result -- a victory over the Bears.
article.headline: Detrick led balanced Sooner attack
article.linkText: Depleted Oklahoma holds off Baylor for win
article.story: WACO, Texas (AP) -- Jason Detrick and his Oklahoma teammates are doing their best to make up for the loss of Kevin Bookout. Detrick scored 14 of his 15 points after halftime to lead a balanced scoring attack, and the No. 25 Sooners beat Baylor 78-67 Wednesday night for their 19th straight win in the series. "Once we found out we would not have Bookout," coach Kelvin Sampson said, "I told our kids when the good Lord closes a door, he opens a window. I don't know who it will be, but somebody will jump through it. So far it's been Jason." Bookout, the Big 12's top field-goal shooter as a freshman last season, has been bothered by a shoulder injury since October. He is scheduled for surgery Friday. Detrick scored in double figures for the third straight game, the second without Bookout. Detrick had averaged just 7.1 points in his eight games before that and slowed by an abdominal strain and a concussion. "I wasn't real frustrated," Detrick said. "I just had to know I was hurt and I had to play through it." Detrick and Lawrence McKenzie led a decisive 14-2 run early in the second half for the Sooners (12-4, 2-3 Big 12), who have consecutive wins after a four-game losing streak that almost knocked them out of the Top 25. All but one Oklahoma player scored, and the other eight had at least eight points each as the Big 12's worst shooting team made half of its shots (24 of 48). "Everybody just tried to share the ball, and whoever was open took the shot," Detrick said. McKenzie had 11 points and 5-foot-7 freshman Drew Lavender had 10 for the Sooners, who shot just 39 percent in their first four Big 12 games. Still, beating Baylor (6-12, 1-4) doesn't exactly qualify as a quality win. The Bears have just seven scholarship players and have lost six of seven games. The Sooners' longest losing streak in five seasons almost dropped them out of the Top 25 for the first time in 45 polls. But they fell only five spots, and not all the way out this week, after ending the drought with a 61-49 win over Kansas State on Saturday. Baylor was within 33-26 early in the second half before Detrick had consecutive baskets to start the game-turning run. His second was a one-handed slam after grabbing his own rebound and driving the lane. McKenzie then scored eight points in just over three minutes. He had a pair of 3-pointers before his layup that made it 47-28 with 12:55 left, and Baylor didn't get closer than 10 points until the final half-minute. "It was hard to come back, we just had too much lack of depth," said Harvey Thomas, who led Baylor with 19 points. Terrance Thomas added 18 points for Baylor. The Bears are 0-17 against Sampson, and their last win over the Sooners was Dec 6, 1977. Oklahoma never trailed after Lavender's 3-pointer five minutes in made it 9-6, but the Sooners didn't put the game away until the second half surge. Even when the Bears went almost five minutes without scoring, the Sooners led just 14-8. The only Oklahoma points in that stretch were Johnnie Gilbert's tip-in and a 3-pointer by Jaison Williams, who got the ball back right after his great save. Williams chased a loose ball, then avoided a backcourt violation by jumping into the air to grab the ball. He threw it back to a teammate before his feet touched the ground, and a couple of passes later made his shot from the top of the key. The Sooners had a 31-21 halftime lead after Jabahri Brown made a layup and added a free throw with 2.8 seconds left. Brown opened the second-half scoring with an quick basket, and Baylor then scored five straight points before Oklahoma's game-turning spurt. "They didn't allow a run to win," Baylor coach Scott Drew said. "They just kept a cushion and answered everything. We could never get started with any kind of rhythm." Oklahoma is 74-12 against Texas teams under in 10 seasons under Sampson, including 58-12 against the state's four Big 12 teams: Baylor, Texas, Texas A&M and Texas Tech.
